**Transcript**:
I'm McKenna Pope. I'm 14 years old. And when I was 13, I convinced one of the largest toy companies, toy makers in the world, Hasbro, to change the way that they marketed one of their best-selling products. So, allow me to tell you about it. So, I have a brother, Gavin. When this whole shebang happened, he was four. He loved to cook. He was always getting ingredients out of the fridge and mixing them into these, needless to say, uneatable concoctions or making invisible macaroni and cheese. He wanted to be a chef really badly. And, so what better gift for someone, for a kid who wanted to be a chef, than an Easy Bake Oven, right? I mean, we all had those when we were little. And he wanted one so badly. But then, he started to realize something. In the commercials and on the boxes for the Easy Bake Oven, Hasbro marketed them specifically to girls. And the way that they did this was they would only feature girls on the boxes or in the commercials, and there would be flowery prints all over the ovens, and it would be in bright pink and purple. Very gender-specific colors to females, right? So, it kind of was sending a message that only girls are supposed to cook. Boys aren't. And this discouraged my brother a lot. He thought that he wasn't supposed to want to be a chef. because that was something girls did. Girls cooked, boys didn't. Or so, the message that Hasbro was sending. And this got me thinking, "God, I wish there was a way I could change this, that I could have my voice heard by Hasbro, so I could ask them and tell them what they were doing wrong and ask them to change it." And that got me thinking about a website that I had learned about a few months prior called Change.org. Change.org is an online petition-sharing platform, where you can create a petition and share it across all these social media networks, through Facebook, through Twitter, through YouTube, through Reddit, through Tumblr, through whatever you can think of. And so, I created a petition, along with a YouTube video that I added to the petition, basically asking Hasbro to change the way that they marketed it, in featuring boys in the commercials and on the boxes, and most of all creating them in less gender-specific colors. So, this petititon started to take off, like humongously fast, you have no idea. I was getting interviewed by all these national news outlets and press outlets, and it was amazing. In three weeks, maybe three and a half, I had 46,000 signatures on this petition. (Applause) Thank you. So, needless to say, it was crazy. Eventually, Hasbro themselves invited me to their headquarters so they could go and unveil their new Easy Bake Oven product to me, in black, silver and blue. It was literally one of the best moments of my life. It was like "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory." That thing was amazing. What I didn't realize at the time, however, was that I had become an activist. I could change something that, even as a kid, or maybe even especially as a kid, my voice mattered. And your voice matters, too! I want to let you know that it's not going to be easy, and it wasn't easy for me because I faced a lot of obstacles. People online, and sometimes even in real life, were disrespectful to me and my family and talked about how the whole thing was a waste of time, and it really discouraged me. And actually, I have some examples because what's better revenge than displaying their idiocy? So, let's see. From username Liquidsword29, interesting usernames we have here, "Disgusting liberal moms making their son's gay." Liquidsword29, really? Really? Okay, how about from Whiteboy77AGS, "People always need something to 'female dog' about." From Jeffrey Gutierrez, "OMG shut up! You just want money and attention." So, it was comments like these that really discouraged me from wanting to make change in the future because I thought, "People don't care. People think it's a waste of time. And people are going to be disrespectful to me and my family." It hurt me. And it made me think, "What's the point in making change in the future?" But then I started to realize something. Haters gonna hate. Come on, say it with me! One, two, three, Haters gonna hate! So let your haters hate, you know what! And make your change because I know you can. I look out into this crowd, and I see 400 people who came out because they wanted to know how they could make a change. And I know that you can, and all of you watching at home can, too, because you have so much that you can do and that you believe in. And you can trade it across all the social media, through Facebook, through Twitter, through YouTube, through Reddit, through Tumblr, through whatever else you can think of. And you can make that change. You can take what you believe in and turn it into a cause and change it. And that spark that you've been hearing about all day today you can use that spark that you have within you and turn it into a fire. Thank you. (Applause)

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
I'm McKenna Pope. I'm 14 years old. And when I was 13, I convinced one of the largest toy companies, toy makers in the world, Hasbro, to change the way that they marketed one of their best-selling products. So, allow me to tell you about it. So, I have a brother, Gavin. When this whole shebang happened, he was four. He loved to cook. He was always getting ingredients out of the fridge and mixing them into these, needless to say, uneatable concoctions or making invisible macaroni and cheese. He wanted to be a chef really badly. And, so what better gift for someone, for a kid who wanted to be a chef, than an Easy Bake Oven, right? I mean, we all had those when we were little. And he wanted one so badly. But then, he started to realize something. In the commercials and on the boxes for the Easy Bake Oven, Hasbro marketed them specifically to girls. And the way that they did this was they would only feature girls on the boxes or in the commercials, and there would be flowery prints all over the ovens, and it would be in bright pink and purple. Very gender-specific colors to females, right? So, it kind of was sending a message that only girls are supposed to cook. Boys aren't. And this discouraged my brother a lot. He thought that he wasn't supposed to want to be a chef. because that was something girls did. Girls cooked, boys didn't. Or so, the message that Hasbro was sending. And this got me thinking, "God, I wish there was a way I could change this, that I could have my voice heard by Hasbro, so I could ask them and tell them what they were doing wrong and ask them to change it." And that got me thinking about a website that I had learned about a few months prior called Change.org. Change.org is an online petition-sharing platform, where you can create a petition and share it across all these social media networks, through Facebook, through Twitter, through YouTube, through Reddit, through Tumblr, through whatever you can think of. And so, I created a petition, along with a YouTube video that I added to the petition, basically asking Hasbro to change the way that they marketed it, in featuring boys in the commercials and on the boxes, and most of all creating them in less gender-specific colors. So, this petititon started to take off, like humongously fast, you have no idea. I was getting interviewed by all these national news outlets and press outlets, and it was amazing. In three weeks, maybe three and a half, I had 46,000 signatures on this petition. (Applause) Thank you. So, needless to say, it was crazy. Eventually, Hasbro themselves invited me to their headquarters so they could go and unveil their new Easy Bake Oven product to me, in black, silver and blue. It was literally one of the best moments of my life. It was like "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory." That thing was amazing. What I didn't realize at the time, however, was that I had become an activist. I could change something that, even as a kid, or maybe even especially as a kid, my voice mattered. And your voice matters, too! I want to let you know that it's not going to be easy, and it wasn't easy for me because I faced a lot of obstacles. People online, and sometimes even in real life, were disrespectful to me and my family and talked about how the whole thing was a waste of time, and it really discouraged me. And actually, I have some examples because what's better revenge than displaying their idiocy? So, let's see. From username Liquidsword29, interesting usernames we have here, "Disgusting liberal moms making their son's gay." Liquidsword29, really? Really? Okay, how about from Whiteboy77AGS, "People always need something to 'female dog' about." From Jeffrey Gutierrez, "OMG shut up! You just want money and attention." So, it was comments like these that really discouraged me from wanting to make change in the future because I thought, "People don't care. People think it's a waste of time. And people are going to be disrespectful to me and my family." It hurt me. And it made me think, "What's the point in making change in the future?" But then I started to realize something. Haters gonna hate. Come on, say it with me! One, two, three, Haters gonna hate! So let your haters hate, you know what! And make your change because I know you can. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
I'm McKenna Pope. I'm 14 years old. And when I was 13, I convinced one of the largest toy companies, toy makers in the world, Hasbro, to change the way that they marketed one of their best-selling products. So, allow me to tell you about it. So, I have a brother, Gavin. When this whole shebang happened, he was four. He loved to cook. He was always getting ingredients out of the fridge and mixing them into these, needless to say, uneatable concoctions or making invisible macaroni and cheese. He wanted to be a chef really badly. And, so what better gift for someone, for a kid who wanted to be a chef, than an Easy Bake Oven, right? I mean, we all had those when we were little. And he wanted one so badly. But then, he started to realize something. In the commercials and on the boxes for the Easy Bake Oven, Hasbro marketed them specifically to girls. And the way that they did this was they would only feature girls on the boxes or in the commercials, and there would be flowery prints all over the ovens, and it would be in bright pink and purple. Very gender-specific colors to females, right? So, it kind of was sending a message that only girls are supposed to cook. Boys aren't. And this discouraged my brother a lot. He thought that he wasn't supposed to want to be a chef. because that was something girls did. Girls cooked, boys didn't. Or so, the message that Hasbro was sending. And this got me thinking, "God, I wish there was a way I could change this, that I could have my voice heard by Hasbro, so I could ask them and tell them what they were doing wrong and ask them to change it." And that got me thinking about a website that I had learned about a few months prior called Change.org. Change.org is an online petition-sharing platform, where you can create a petition and share it across all these social media networks, through Facebook, through Twitter, through YouTube, through Reddit, through Tumblr, through whatever you can think of. And so, I created a petition, along with a YouTube video that I added to the petition, basically asking Hasbro to change the way that they marketed it, in featuring boys in the commercials and on the boxes, and most of all creating them in less gender-specific colors. So, this petititon started to take off, like humongously fast, you have no idea. I was getting interviewed by all these national news outlets and press outlets, and it was amazing. In three weeks, maybe three and a half, I had 46,000 signatures on this petition. (Applause) Thank you. So, needless to say, it was crazy. Eventually, Hasbro themselves invited me to their headquarters so they could go and unveil their new Easy Bake Oven product to me, in black, silver and blue. It was literally one of the best moments of my life. It was like "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory." That thing was amazing. What I didn't realize at the time, however, was that I had become an activist. I could change something that, even as a kid, or maybe even especially as a kid, my voice mattered. And your voice matters, too! I want to let you know that it's not going to be easy, and it wasn't easy for me because I faced a lot of obstacles. People online, and sometimes even in real life, were disrespectful to me and my family and talked about how the whole thing was a waste of time, and it really discouraged me. And actually, I have some examples because what's better revenge than displaying their idiocy? So, let's see. From username Liquidsword29, interesting usernames we have here, "Disgusting liberal moms making their son's gay." Liquidsword29, really? Really? Okay, how about from Whiteboy77AGS, "People always need something to 'female dog' about." From Jeffrey Gutierrez, "OMG shut up! You just want money and attention." So, it was comments like these that really discouraged me from wanting to make change in the future because I thought, "People don't care. People think it's a waste of time. And people are going to be disrespectful to me and my family." It hurt me. And it made me think, "What's the point in making change in the future?" But then I started to realize something. Haters gonna hate. Come on, say it with me! One, two, three, Haters gonna hate! So let your haters hate, you know what! And make your change because I know you can. I look out into this crowd, and I see 400 people who came out because they wanted to know how they could make a change. And I know that you can, and all of you watching at home can, too, because you have so much that you can do and that you believe in. And you can trade it across all the social media, through Facebook, through Twitter, through YouTube, through Reddit, through Tumblr, through whatever else you can think of. And you can make that change. You can take what you believe in and turn it into a cause and change it. And that spark that you've been hearing about all day today you can use that spark that you have within you and turn it into a fire. Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: You have to be famous or be a celebrity to start and successfully win with an online petition.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: At what age did McKenna Pope successfully petition Hasbro to change their marketing strategy for the Easy Bake Oven? Options: A. 10 years old, B. 13 years old, C. 16 years old, D. 18 years old Correct Option: B
Question 2: How many signatures did McKenna Pope's petition gain in approximately three and a half weeks? Options: A. 10,000 signatures, B. 20,000 signatures, C. 46,000 signatures, D. 50,000 signatures Correct Option: C
Question 3: Why was McKenna Pope's brother, Gavin, discouraged from wanting an Easy Bake Oven? Options: A. Because he didn't like cooking, B. Because the Easy Bake Oven was too expensive, C. Because the Easy Bake Oven was marketed specifically to girls, D. Because he was too young Correct Option: C
Question 4: What message did McKenna Pope believe the Easy Bake Oven's marketing strategy was sending to children? Options: A. That cooking is a fun activity for everyone, B. That only girls are supposed to cook, and boys are not, C. That the Easy Bake Oven is a toy for older kids, D. That cooking is a difficult task Correct Option: B
Question 5: What platform did McKenna Pope use to create and share her petition? Options: A. Facebook, B. Change.org, C. Twitter, D. YouTube Correct Option: B
Question 6: What can McKenna Pope's story inspire others to do? Options: A. Give up on their goals, B. Take action and make a difference in their own communities, C. Wait for someone else to make a change, D. Ignore social issues Correct Option: B
Question 7: What does McKenna Pope's experience highlight about the impact of marketing strategies on children? Options: A. That they have no impact on children's perceptions, B. That they can perpetuate stereotypes and limit children's interests, C. That they are only effective for girls, D. That they are only effective for boys Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the outcome of McKenna Pope's petition and meeting with Hasbro? Options: A. Hasbro refused to change their marketing strategy, B. Hasbro changed the color of the Easy Bake Oven but not the marketing strategy, C. Hasbro unveiled a new Easy Bake Oven product with a more inclusive marketing strategy, D. Hasbro discontinued the Easy Bake Oven Correct Option: C
Question 9: What lesson did McKenna Pope learn from her experience with negative comments online? Options: A. That she should give up on her goals, B. That she should ignore the comments and focus on her goal, C. That she should respond to each comment individually, D. That she should delete her social media accounts Correct Option: B
Question 10: What does McKenna Pope's story demonstrate about the potential for individual action to create change? Options: A. That individual action is ineffective in creating change, B. That individual action can lead to significant positive change, C. That individual action is only effective for small issues, D. That individual action is only effective for local issues Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is necessary to evaluate the effectiveness of McKenna Pope's petition and the subsequent change in Hasbro's marketing strategy? Options: A. Considering the impact on the target audience and the broader community, B. Ignoring the potential consequences, C. Focusing only on the short-term effects, D. Disregarding the role of social media Correct Option: A
Question 12: What does McKenna Pope's story highlight about the importance of perseverance in the face of obstacles? Options: A. That obstacles are insurmountable and one should give up, B. That perseverance is key to overcoming obstacles and achieving goals, C. That obstacles are only minor setbacks, D. That perseverance is only necessary for small goals Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 10: What does McKenna Pope's story demonstrate about the potential for individual action to create change?**

Options: A. That individual action is ineffective in creating change, B. That individual action can lead to significant positive change, C. That individual action is only effective for small issues, D. That individual action is only effective for local issues

Correct Option: B

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of intent, options, and content. The ground truth MCQ asks whether one needs to be famous or a celebrity to start and successfully win with an online petition, implying that individual action can lead to change. Question 10 explicitly asks about the potential for individual action to create change, making it the most similar generated MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: **10**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 5, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
I'm McKenna Pope. I'm 14 years old. And when I was 13, I convinced one of the largest toy companies, toy makers in the world, Hasbro, to change the way that they marketed one of their best-selling products. So, allow me to tell you about it. So, I have a brother, Gavin. When this whole shebang happened, he was four. He loved to cook. He was always getting ingredients out of the fridge and mixing them into these, needless to say, uneatable concoctions or making invisible macaroni and cheese. He wanted to be a chef really badly. And, so what better gift for someone, for a kid who wanted to be a chef, than an Easy Bake Oven, right? I mean, we all had those when we were little. And he wanted one so badly. But then, he started to realize something. In the commercials and on the boxes for the Easy Bake Oven, Hasbro marketed them specifically to girls. And the way that they did this was they would only feature girls on the boxes or in the commercials, and there would be flowery prints all over the ovens, and it would be in bright pink and purple. Very gender-specific colors to females, right? So, it kind of was sending a message that only girls are supposed to cook. Boys aren't. And this discouraged my brother a lot. He thought that he wasn't supposed to want to be a chef. because that was something girls did. Girls cooked, boys didn't. Or so, the message that Hasbro was sending. And this got me thinking, "God, I wish there was a way I could change this, that I could have my voice heard by Hasbro, so I could ask them and tell them what they were doing wrong and ask them to change it." And that got me thinking about a website that I had learned about a few months prior called Change.org. Change.org is an online petition-sharing platform, where you can create a petition and share it across all these social media networks, through Facebook, through Twitter, through YouTube, through Reddit, through Tumblr, through whatever you can think of. And so, I created a petition, along with a YouTube video that I added to the petition, basically asking Hasbro to change the way that they marketed it, in featuring boys in the commercials and on the boxes, and most of all creating them in less gender-specific colors. So, this petititon started to take off, like humongously fast, you have no idea. I was getting interviewed by all these national news outlets and press outlets, and it was amazing. In three weeks, maybe three and a half, I had 46,000 signatures on this petition. (Applause) Thank you. So, needless to say, it was crazy. Eventually, Hasbro themselves invited me to their headquarters so they could go and unveil their new Easy Bake Oven product to me, in black, silver and blue. It was literally one of the best moments of my life. It was like "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory." That thing was amazing. What I didn't realize at the time, however, was that I had become an activist. I could change something that, even as a kid, or maybe even especially as a kid, my voice mattered. And your voice matters, too! I want to let you know that it's not going to be easy, and it wasn't easy for me because I faced a lot of obstacles. People online, and sometimes even in real life, were disrespectful to me and my family and talked about how the whole thing was a waste of time, and it really discouraged me. And actually, I have some examples because what's better revenge than displaying their idiocy? So, let's see. From username Liquidsword29, interesting usernames we have here, "Disgusting liberal moms making their son's gay." Liquidsword29, really? Really? Okay, how about from Whiteboy77AGS, "People always need something to 'female dog' about." From Jeffrey Gutierrez, "OMG shut up! You just want money and attention." So, it was comments like these that really discouraged me from wanting to make change in the future because I thought, "People don't care. People think it's a waste of time. And people are going to be disrespectful to me and my family." It hurt me. And it made me think, "What's the point in making change in the future?" But then I started to realize something. Haters gonna hate. Come on, say it with me! One, two, three, Haters gonna hate! So let your haters hate, you know what! And make your change because I know you can. I look out into this crowd, and I see 400 people who came out because they wanted to know how they could make a change. And I know that you can, and all of you watching at home can, too, because you have so much that you can do and that you believe in. And you can trade it across all the social media, through Facebook, through Twitter, through YouTube, through Reddit, through Tumblr, through whatever else you can think of. And you can make that change. You can take what you believe in and turn it into a cause and change it. And that spark that you've been hearing about all day today you can use that spark that you have within you and turn it into a fire. Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When starting a petition to create change, will everyone agree with you?
Options: A. Yes, B. Not everyone, but it's really east to convince them, C. Unfortunately not, but with perseverance you will succeed, and as McKenna says, "Haters gonna hate!", D. Nobody will agree with you
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
By 1973, Harvey Milk had already been many things: naval officer, high school teacher, bit-part actor, and wandering hippie. But as he embarked on yet another life 
running a camera shop in San Francisco, he already found himself distracted. From the Watergate hearings 
on national news, to the teacher who had to rent a projector
when her school couldn’t afford one, Harvey saw a desperate need 
for political reform. Milk strongly believed that tight knit 
neighborhoods were essential to the fabric of the city, and that government should solve those 
community’s most practical problems. From fixing potholes and putting 
up stop signs, to promoting a friendly culture 
of cooperation, Milk envisioned a more personal 
approach to local government. This philosophy led him to run 
for the city’s Board of Supervisors as the representative 
for his own district, which included the heart of 
American gay culture, the Castro. At this time, police brutality, 
discrimination and media stereotyping plagued the LGBT community, labeling Harvey and his supporters as 
political outsiders. But Milk refused to 
downplay his sexuality. He was sure that gay rights could never 
be won from the closet, and he saw the Castro as one of many minorities without 
representation in city politics. Milk was determined to bring these 
basic government services to all of San Francisco’s disenfranchised 
groups, regardless of race, age, or sexuality. But despite his flair for public speaking and open-hearted approach, voters couldn’t see Milk’s radical vision. In 1973, he lost his first bid for 
the Board of Supervisors. In 1975, he lost again. A year later, he ran for the California 
Assembly– and lost. Yet he tirelessly continued 
to support his district, befriending bartenders, construction 
unions, and local Chinese grocers. This earned him the affectionate title, 
the "mayor of Castro Street.” And when he ran his third campaign for 
the Board of Supervisors in 1977, Harvey finally won the seat– becoming one of the first openly gay 
public officials in US history. Elated, Milk arrived in office determined 
to make lasting change. He immediately introduced a bill outlawing
discrimination on the grounds of sexuality and launched a major clean-up of the city. But not everyone was happy 
with this direction. Anti-gay sentiment was gaining national 
momentum, especially in the form of 
California’s Proposition 6. The proposition, which sought 
to make it illegal for homosexuals to work 
in Californian schools, would prove to be the biggest battle 
of Milk’s career. Supporters of Prop 6 attacked 
the LGBT community, calling them unfit to work with students. But Milk urged them not to hide in fear: “Come out to your relatives. Come out to your friends, 
if indeed they are your friends. Come out to your neighbors, 
to your fellow workers… break down the myths. Destroy the lies and distortions. For your sake. For their sake.” Alongside other activists, he ran an incandescent campaign 
against hate. On November 7, 1978, Prop 6 was defeated in a landslide. It was proof that Milk’s message was 
gaining traction. But just twenty days after this 
inspiring victory, he was assassinated at City Hall– killed alongside San Francisco 
Mayor George Moscone. Both men had been murdered by Dan White, a former fellow supervisor, who had positioned himself against those 
he called "radicals, social deviates and incorrigibles.” He had frequently clashed with Harvey 
at Board meetings, and resented the spirit of change 
which Milk personified for many. The night of Milk's murder, thousands marched by candlelight 
through the city. In the wake of this tragedy, yet another injustice arose. In a highly controversial verdict, White received a sentence of only seven 
years and eight months– a decision that sparked uproar 
throughout the city in what became known as 
the White Night Riots. But even after his death, Milk continued to preach 
his hopeful cause. He left his friends and followers a total 
of three different tapes to be played in the event 
of his assassination. They leave us with a call to action, and a reminder that everyone is welcome
in the fight against injustice: "I ask for the movement to continue… and if a bullet should enter my brain, let that bullet destroy 
every closet door…”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many times did Harvey Milk run for public office before he was finally elected to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors?
Options: A. 2, B. 6, C. 4, D. 3
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Harvey Milk's occupation before running a camera shop in San Francisco? Options: A. High school teacher and actor, B. Naval officer and politician, C. High school teacher, actor, naval officer, and hippie, D. Businessman and lawyer Correct Option: C
Question 2: Who assassinated Harvey Milk at City Hall alongside Mayor George Moscone? Options: A. Dan White, a former fellow supervisor, B. A disgruntled employee, C. A member of the LGBT community, D. A police officer Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the core of Harvey Milk's vision for local government? Options: A. A more centralized approach to governance, B. A focus on promoting cooperation and fixing practical problems, C. A stronger emphasis on law enforcement, D. A reduction in government services Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why did Harvey Milk refuse to downplay his sexuality? Options: A. He believed it would harm his political career, B. He thought it would alienate his supporters, C. He believed gay rights could not be won from the closet, D. He wanted to avoid controversy Correct Option: C
Question 5: A community is struggling with a lack of representation in local government. What approach, inspired by Harvey Milk, could be used to address this issue? Options: A. Organizing protests and demonstrations, B. Focusing on community-focused government initiatives and promoting cooperation, C. Reducing government services to marginalized groups, D. Increasing law enforcement presence Correct Option: B
Question 6: A social justice movement is seeking to address police brutality and media stereotyping. What strategy, inspired by Harvey Milk, could be employed? Options: A. Using social media to raise awareness, B. Applying Milk's approach to addressing social injustices by promoting cooperation and breaking down myths, C. Focusing solely on policy changes, D. Ignoring the issues and hoping they resolve themselves Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the relationship between Harvey Milk's personal experiences and his political philosophy? Options: A. His experiences had no impact on his philosophy, B. His experiences shaped his emphasis on community-focused government and promoting cooperation, C. His experiences led him to focus solely on LGBT rights, D. His experiences made him more conservative Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the impact of Harvey Milk's assassination on the LGBT community? Options: A. It had no significant impact, B. It led to a decline in activism and mobilization, C. It sparked widespread outrage and protests, including the White Night Riots, D. It resulted in increased representation in politics Correct Option: C
Question 9: How could Harvey Milk's emphasis on community-focused government be combined with modern-day initiatives for social justice? Options: A. By ignoring the needs of marginalized groups, B. By integrating community-focused government with strategies for promoting social justice and addressing intersecting injustices, C. By reducing government services to marginalized groups, D. By focusing solely on policy changes Correct Option: B
Question 10: What could be the result of integrating Harvey Milk's message of coming out and breaking down myths with contemporary strategies for promoting LGBT rights? Options: A. A decline in activism and mobilization, B. Increased representation and inclusivity in politics, C. A stronger emphasis on law enforcement, D. A reduction in government services Correct Option: B
Question 11: What can be said about the effectiveness of Harvey Milk's approach to addressing social injustices and promoting LGBT rights? Options: A. It was ineffective and led to no significant change, B. It was moderately successful, but had limited impact, C. It was highly effective in promoting social justice and LGBT rights, and continues to inspire contemporary movements, D. It was only effective in the short-term Correct Option: C
Question 12: What justification can be made for the importance of representation and inclusivity in politics, using Harvey Milk's legacy as an example? Options: A. Representation and inclusivity are not important in politics, B. Representation and inclusivity are only important for marginalized groups, C. Representation and inclusivity are crucial in politics, as they allow for diverse perspectives and promote social justice, D. Representation and inclusivity are only important for LGBT individuals Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the number of times Harvey Milk ran for public office before being elected to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors. While there isn't a direct match among the generated MCQs, Question 1 mentions Harvey Milk's occupations before running a camera shop in San Francisco, which is somewhat related to his life before being elected.

However, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is closest to the ground truth MCQ in terms of intent and content, I would suggest Question 7. This question asks about the relationship between Harvey Milk's personal experiences and his political philosophy, which is somewhat related to his journey and attempts to get elected.

But, if I'm being completely honest, none of the generated MCQs are a great match for the ground truth MCQ.

That being said, if I had to provide an index, I would say that Question 7 is the most similar generated MCQ, with the understanding that it's not a direct match.

Index: 7

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
By 1973, Harvey Milk had already been many things: naval officer, high school teacher, bit-part actor, and wandering hippie. But as he embarked on yet another life 
running a camera shop in San Francisco, he already found himself distracted. From the Watergate hearings 
on national news, to the teacher who had to rent a projector
when her school couldn’t afford one, Harvey saw a desperate need 
for political reform. Milk strongly believed that tight knit 
neighborhoods were essential to the fabric of the city, and that government should solve those 
community’s most practical problems. From fixing potholes and putting 
up stop signs, to promoting a friendly culture 
of cooperation, Milk envisioned a more personal 
approach to local government. This philosophy led him to run 
for the city’s Board of Supervisors as the representative 
for his own district, which included the heart of 
American gay culture, the Castro. At this time, police brutality, 
discrimination and media stereotyping plagued the LGBT community, labeling Harvey and his supporters as 
political outsiders. But Milk refused to 
downplay his sexuality. He was sure that gay rights could never 
be won from the closet, and he saw the Castro as one of many minorities without 
representation in city politics. Milk was determined to bring these 
basic government services to all of San Francisco’s disenfranchised 
groups, regardless of race, age, or sexuality. But despite his flair for public speaking and open-hearted approach, voters couldn’t see Milk’s radical vision. In 1973, he lost his first bid for 
the Board of Supervisors. In 1975, he lost again. A year later, he ran for the California 
Assembly– and lost. Yet he tirelessly continued 
to support his district, befriending bartenders, construction 
unions, and local Chinese grocers. This earned him the affectionate title, 
the "mayor of Castro Street.” And when he ran his third campaign for 
the Board of Supervisors in 1977, Harvey finally won the seat– becoming one of the first openly gay 
public officials in US history. Elated, Milk arrived in office determined 
to make lasting change. He immediately introduced a bill outlawing
discrimination on the grounds of sexuality and launched a major clean-up of the city. But not everyone was happy 
with this direction. Anti-gay sentiment was gaining national 
momentum, especially in the form of 
California’s Proposition 6. The proposition, which sought 
to make it illegal for homosexuals to work 
in Californian schools, would prove to be the biggest battle 
of Milk’s career. Supporters of Prop 6 attacked 
the LGBT community, calling them unfit to work with students. But Milk urged them not to hide in fear: “Come out to your relatives. Come out to your friends, 
if indeed they are your friends. Come out to your neighbors, 
to your fellow workers… break down the myths. Destroy the lies and distortions. For your sake. For their sake.” Alongside other activists, he ran an incandescent campaign 
against hate. On November 7, 1978, Prop 6 was defeated in a landslide. It was proof that Milk’s message was 
gaining traction. But just twenty days after this 
inspiring victory, he was assassinated at City Hall– killed alongside San Francisco 
Mayor George Moscone. Both men had been murdered by Dan White, a former fellow supervisor, who had positioned himself against those 
he called "radicals, social deviates and incorrigibles.” He had frequently clashed with Harvey 
at Board meetings, and resented the spirit of change 
which Milk personified for many. The night of Milk's murder, thousands marched by candlelight 
through the city. In the wake of this tragedy, yet another injustice arose. In a highly controversial verdict, White received a sentence of only seven 
years and eight months– a decision that sparked uproar 
throughout the city in what became known as 
the White Night Riots. But even after his death, Milk continued to preach 
his hopeful cause. He left his friends and followers a total 
of three different tapes to be played in the event 
of his assassination. They leave us with a call to action, and a reminder that everyone is welcome
in the fight against injustice: "I ask for the movement to continue… and if a bullet should enter my brain, let that bullet destroy 
every closet door…”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What jobs did Harvey Milk hold before he was elected to public office?
Options: A. Teacher, B. Naval Officer, C. Actor, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Harvey Milk's occupation before running a camera shop in San Francisco? Options: A. High school teacher and actor, B. Naval officer and politician, C. High school teacher, actor, naval officer, and hippie, D. Businessman and lawyer Correct Option: C
Question 2: Who assassinated Harvey Milk at City Hall alongside Mayor George Moscone? Options: A. Dan White, a former fellow supervisor, B. A disgruntled employee, C. A member of the LGBT community, D. A police officer Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the core of Harvey Milk's vision for local government? Options: A. A more centralized approach to governance, B. A focus on promoting cooperation and fixing practical problems, C. A stronger emphasis on law enforcement, D. A reduction in government services Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why did Harvey Milk refuse to downplay his sexuality? Options: A. He believed it would harm his political career, B. He thought it would alienate his supporters, C. He believed gay rights could not be won from the closet, D. He wanted to avoid controversy Correct Option: C
Question 5: A community is struggling with a lack of representation in local government. What approach, inspired by Harvey Milk, could be used to address this issue? Options: A. Organizing protests and demonstrations, B. Focusing on community-focused government initiatives and promoting cooperation, C. Reducing government services to marginalized groups, D. Increasing law enforcement presence Correct Option: B
Question 6: A social justice movement is seeking to address police brutality and media stereotyping. What strategy, inspired by Harvey Milk, could be employed? Options: A. Using social media to raise awareness, B. Applying Milk's approach to addressing social injustices by promoting cooperation and breaking down myths, C. Focusing solely on policy changes, D. Ignoring the issues and hoping they resolve themselves Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the relationship between Harvey Milk's personal experiences and his political philosophy? Options: A. His experiences had no impact on his philosophy, B. His experiences shaped his emphasis on community-focused government and promoting cooperation, C. His experiences led him to focus solely on LGBT rights, D. His experiences made him more conservative Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the impact of Harvey Milk's assassination on the LGBT community? Options: A. It had no significant impact, B. It led to a decline in activism and mobilization, C. It sparked widespread outrage and protests, including the White Night Riots, D. It resulted in increased representation in politics Correct Option: C
Question 9: How could Harvey Milk's emphasis on community-focused government be combined with modern-day initiatives for social justice? Options: A. By ignoring the needs of marginalized groups, B. By integrating community-focused government with strategies for promoting social justice and addressing intersecting injustices, C. By reducing government services to marginalized groups, D. By focusing solely on policy changes Correct Option: B
Question 10: What could be the result of integrating Harvey Milk's message of coming out and breaking down myths with contemporary strategies for promoting LGBT rights? Options: A. A decline in activism and mobilization, B. Increased representation and inclusivity in politics, C. A stronger emphasis on law enforcement, D. A reduction in government services Correct Option: B
Question 11: What can be said about the effectiveness of Harvey Milk's approach to addressing social injustices and promoting LGBT rights? Options: A. It was ineffective and led to no significant change, B. It was moderately successful, but had limited impact, C. It was highly effective in promoting social justice and LGBT rights, and continues to inspire contemporary movements, D. It was only effective in the short-term Correct Option: C
Question 12: What justification can be made for the importance of representation and inclusivity in politics, using Harvey Milk's legacy as an example? Options: A. Representation and inclusivity are not important in politics, B. Representation and inclusivity are only important for marginalized groups, C. Representation and inclusivity are crucial in politics, as they allow for diverse perspectives and promote social justice, D. Representation and inclusivity are only important for LGBT individuals Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of content, as it asks about Harvey Milk's occupations before he was elected to public office. The options provided in Question 1 also align with the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option (C) listing multiple occupations (high school teacher, actor, naval officer, and hippie) that are mentioned in the ground truth MCQ. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
By 1973, Harvey Milk had already been many things: naval officer, high school teacher, bit-part actor, and wandering hippie. But as he embarked on yet another life 
running a camera shop in San Francisco, he already found himself distracted. From the Watergate hearings 
on national news, to the teacher who had to rent a projector
when her school couldn’t afford one, Harvey saw a desperate need 
for political reform. Milk strongly believed that tight knit 
neighborhoods were essential to the fabric of the city, and that government should solve those 
community’s most practical problems. From fixing potholes and putting 
up stop signs, to promoting a friendly culture 
of cooperation, Milk envisioned a more personal 
approach to local government. This philosophy led him to run 
for the city’s Board of Supervisors as the representative 
for his own district, which included the heart of 
American gay culture, the Castro. At this time, police brutality, 
discrimination and media stereotyping plagued the LGBT community, labeling Harvey and his supporters as 
political outsiders. But Milk refused to 
downplay his sexuality. He was sure that gay rights could never 
be won from the closet, and he saw the Castro as one of many minorities without 
representation in city politics. Milk was determined to bring these 
basic government services to all of San Francisco’s disenfranchised 
groups, regardless of race, age, or sexuality. But despite his flair for public speaking and open-hearted approach, voters couldn’t see Milk’s radical vision. In 1973, he lost his first bid for 
the Board of Supervisors. In 1975, he lost again. A year later, he ran for the California 
Assembly– and lost. Yet he tirelessly continued 
to support his district, befriending bartenders, construction 
unions, and local Chinese grocers. This earned him the affectionate title, 
the "mayor of Castro Street.” And when he ran his third campaign for 
the Board of Supervisors in 1977, Harvey finally won the seat– becoming one of the first openly gay 
public officials in US history. Elated, Milk arrived in office determined 
to make lasting change. He immediately introduced a bill outlawing
discrimination on the grounds of sexuality and launched a major clean-up of the city. But not everyone was happy 
with this direction. Anti-gay sentiment was gaining national 
momentum, especially in the form of 
California’s Proposition 6. The proposition, which sought 
to make it illegal for homosexuals to work 
in Californian schools, would prove to be the biggest battle 
of Milk’s career. Supporters of Prop 6 attacked 
the LGBT community, calling them unfit to work with students. But Milk urged them not to hide in fear: “Come out to your relatives. Come out to your friends, 
if indeed they are your friends. Come out to your neighbors, 
to your fellow workers… break down the myths. Destroy the lies and distortions. For your sake. For their sake.” Alongside other activists, he ran an incandescent campaign 
against hate. On November 7, 1978, Prop 6 was defeated in a landslide. It was proof that Milk’s message was 
gaining traction. But just twenty days after this 
inspiring victory, he was assassinated at City Hall– killed alongside San Francisco 
Mayor George Moscone. Both men had been murdered by Dan White, a former fellow supervisor, who had positioned himself against those 
he called "radicals, social deviates and incorrigibles.” He had frequently clashed with Harvey 
at Board meetings, and resented the spirit of change 
which Milk personified for many. The night of Milk's murder, thousands marched by candlelight 
through the city. In the wake of this tragedy, yet another injustice arose. In a highly controversial verdict, White received a sentence of only seven 
years and eight months– a decision that sparked uproar 
throughout the city in what became known as 
the White Night Riots. But even after his death, Milk continued to preach 
his hopeful cause. He left his friends and followers a total 
of three different tapes to be played in the event 
of his assassination. They leave us with a call to action, and a reminder that everyone is welcome
in the fight against injustice: "I ask for the movement to continue… and if a bullet should enter my brain, let that bullet destroy 
every closet door…”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In what year was Harvey Milk elected to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors?
Options: A. 1982, B. 2005, C. 1977, D. 1969
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Harvey Milk's occupation before running a camera shop in San Francisco? Options: A. High school teacher and actor, B. Naval officer and politician, C. High school teacher, actor, naval officer, and hippie, D. Businessman and lawyer Correct Option: C
Question 2: Who assassinated Harvey Milk at City Hall alongside Mayor George Moscone? Options: A. Dan White, a former fellow supervisor, B. A disgruntled employee, C. A member of the LGBT community, D. A police officer Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the core of Harvey Milk's vision for local government? Options: A. A more centralized approach to governance, B. A focus on promoting cooperation and fixing practical problems, C. A stronger emphasis on law enforcement, D. A reduction in government services Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why did Harvey Milk refuse to downplay his sexuality? Options: A. He believed it would harm his political career, B. He thought it would alienate his supporters, C. He believed gay rights could not be won from the closet, D. He wanted to avoid controversy Correct Option: C
Question 5: A community is struggling with a lack of representation in local government. What approach, inspired by Harvey Milk, could be used to address this issue? Options: A. Organizing protests and demonstrations, B. Focusing on community-focused government initiatives and promoting cooperation, C. Reducing government services to marginalized groups, D. Increasing law enforcement presence Correct Option: B
Question 6: A social justice movement is seeking to address police brutality and media stereotyping. What strategy, inspired by Harvey Milk, could be employed? Options: A. Using social media to raise awareness, B. Applying Milk's approach to addressing social injustices by promoting cooperation and breaking down myths, C. Focusing solely on policy changes, D. Ignoring the issues and hoping they resolve themselves Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the relationship between Harvey Milk's personal experiences and his political philosophy? Options: A. His experiences had no impact on his philosophy, B. His experiences shaped his emphasis on community-focused government and promoting cooperation, C. His experiences led him to focus solely on LGBT rights, D. His experiences made him more conservative Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the impact of Harvey Milk's assassination on the LGBT community? Options: A. It had no significant impact, B. It led to a decline in activism and mobilization, C. It sparked widespread outrage and protests, including the White Night Riots, D. It resulted in increased representation in politics Correct Option: C
Question 9: How could Harvey Milk's emphasis on community-focused government be combined with modern-day initiatives for social justice? Options: A. By ignoring the needs of marginalized groups, B. By integrating community-focused government with strategies for promoting social justice and addressing intersecting injustices, C. By reducing government services to marginalized groups, D. By focusing solely on policy changes Correct Option: B
Question 10: What could be the result of integrating Harvey Milk's message of coming out and breaking down myths with contemporary strategies for promoting LGBT rights? Options: A. A decline in activism and mobilization, B. Increased representation and inclusivity in politics, C. A stronger emphasis on law enforcement, D. A reduction in government services Correct Option: B
Question 11: What can be said about the effectiveness of Harvey Milk's approach to addressing social injustices and promoting LGBT rights? Options: A. It was ineffective and led to no significant change, B. It was moderately successful, but had limited impact, C. It was highly effective in promoting social justice and LGBT rights, and continues to inspire contemporary movements, D. It was only effective in the short-term Correct Option: C
Question 12: What justification can be made for the importance of representation and inclusivity in politics, using Harvey Milk's legacy as an example? Options: A. Representation and inclusivity are not important in politics, B. Representation and inclusivity are only important for marginalized groups, C. Representation and inclusivity are crucial in politics, as they allow for diverse perspectives and promote social justice, D. Representation and inclusivity are only important for LGBT individuals Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the year Harvey Milk was elected to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 1 mentions Harvey Milk's occupation before running a camera shop in San Francisco and includes a correct option that mentions his occupation as a high school teacher, actor, naval officer, and hippie, which is somewhat related to his life before being elected.

However, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is closest to the ground truth MCQ in terms of intent and content, I would suggest Question 3, which asks about the core of Harvey Milk's vision for local government. This question is not directly related to the ground truth MCQ but is somewhat related to Harvey Milk's role as a supervisor.

But since none of the questions match the ground truth MCQ, I will provide an answer that indicates that there is no matching generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
By 1973, Harvey Milk had already been many things: naval officer, high school teacher, bit-part actor, and wandering hippie. But as he embarked on yet another life 
running a camera shop in San Francisco, he already found himself distracted. From the Watergate hearings 
on national news, to the teacher who had to rent a projector
when her school couldn’t afford one, Harvey saw a desperate need 
for political reform. Milk strongly believed that tight knit 
neighborhoods were essential to the fabric of the city, and that government should solve those 
community’s most practical problems. From fixing potholes and putting 
up stop signs, to promoting a friendly culture 
of cooperation, Milk envisioned a more personal 
approach to local government. This philosophy led him to run 
for the city’s Board of Supervisors as the representative 
for his own district, which included the heart of 
American gay culture, the Castro. At this time, police brutality, 
discrimination and media stereotyping plagued the LGBT community, labeling Harvey and his supporters as 
political outsiders. But Milk refused to 
downplay his sexuality. He was sure that gay rights could never 
be won from the closet, and he saw the Castro as one of many minorities without 
representation in city politics. Milk was determined to bring these 
basic government services to all of San Francisco’s disenfranchised 
groups, regardless of race, age, or sexuality. But despite his flair for public speaking and open-hearted approach, voters couldn’t see Milk’s radical vision. In 1973, he lost his first bid for 
the Board of Supervisors. In 1975, he lost again. A year later, he ran for the California 
Assembly– and lost. Yet he tirelessly continued 
to support his district, befriending bartenders, construction 
unions, and local Chinese grocers. This earned him the affectionate title, 
the "mayor of Castro Street.” And when he ran his third campaign for 
the Board of Supervisors in 1977, Harvey finally won the seat– becoming one of the first openly gay 
public officials in US history. Elated, Milk arrived in office determined 
to make lasting change. He immediately introduced a bill outlawing
discrimination on the grounds of sexuality and launched a major clean-up of the city. But not everyone was happy 
with this direction. Anti-gay sentiment was gaining national 
momentum, especially in the form of 
California’s Proposition 6. The proposition, which sought 
to make it illegal for homosexuals to work 
in Californian schools, would prove to be the biggest battle 
of Milk’s career. Supporters of Prop 6 attacked 
the LGBT community, calling them unfit to work with students. But Milk urged them not to hide in fear: “Come out to your relatives. Come out to your friends, 
if indeed they are your friends. Come out to your neighbors, 
to your fellow workers… break down the myths. Destroy the lies and distortions. For your sake. For their sake.” Alongside other activists, he ran an incandescent campaign 
against hate. On November 7, 1978, Prop 6 was defeated in a landslide. It was proof that Milk’s message was 
gaining traction. But just twenty days after this 
inspiring victory, he was assassinated at City Hall– killed alongside San Francisco 
Mayor George Moscone. Both men had been murdered by Dan White, a former fellow supervisor, who had positioned himself against those 
he called "radicals, social deviates and incorrigibles.” He had frequently clashed with Harvey 
at Board meetings, and resented the spirit of change 
which Milk personified for many. The night of Milk's murder, thousands marched by candlelight 
through the city. In the wake of this tragedy, yet another injustice arose. In a highly controversial verdict, White received a sentence of only seven 
years and eight months– a decision that sparked uproar 
throughout the city in what became known as 
the White Night Riots. But even after his death, Milk continued to preach 
his hopeful cause. He left his friends and followers a total 
of three different tapes to be played in the event 
of his assassination. They leave us with a call to action, and a reminder that everyone is welcome
in the fight against injustice: "I ask for the movement to continue… and if a bullet should enter my brain, let that bullet destroy 
every closet door…”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Harvey Milk championed civil rights for:
Options: A. African Americans, B. Latinos, C. Gay people, D. All of the above
Correct Option: C

Question 3: What was the core of Harvey Milk's vision for local government? Options: A. A more centralized approach to governance, B. A focus on promoting cooperation and fixing practical problems, C. A stronger emphasis on law enforcement, D. A reduction in government services Correct Option: B
Question 4: Why did Harvey Milk refuse to downplay his sexuality? Options: A. He believed it would harm his political career, B. He thought it would alienate his supporters, C. He believed gay rights could not be won from the closet, D. He wanted to avoid controversy Correct Option: C

By focusing solely on policy changes Correct Option: B

A decline in activism and mobilization, B. Increased representation and inclusivity in politics, C. A stronger emphasis on law enforcement, D. A reduction in government services Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 6, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
By 1973, Harvey Milk had already been many things: naval officer, high school teacher, bit-part actor, and wandering hippie. But as he embarked on yet another life 
running a camera shop in San Francisco, he already found himself distracted. From the Watergate hearings 
on national news, to the teacher who had to rent a projector
when her school couldn’t afford one, Harvey saw a desperate need 
for political reform. Milk strongly believed that tight knit 
neighborhoods were essential to the fabric of the city, and that government should solve those 
community’s most practical problems. From fixing potholes and putting 
up stop signs, to promoting a friendly culture 
of cooperation, Milk envisioned a more personal 
approach to local government. This philosophy led him to run 
for the city’s Board of Supervisors as the representative 
for his own district, which included the heart of 
American gay culture, the Castro. At this time, police brutality, 
discrimination and media stereotyping plagued the LGBT community, labeling Harvey and his supporters as 
political outsiders. But Milk refused to 
downplay his sexuality. He was sure that gay rights could never 
be won from the closet, and he saw the Castro as one of many minorities without 
representation in city politics. Milk was determined to bring these 
basic government services to all of San Francisco’s disenfranchised 
groups, regardless of race, age, or sexuality. But despite his flair for public speaking and open-hearted approach, voters couldn’t see Milk’s radical vision. In 1973, he lost his first bid for 
the Board of Supervisors. In 1975, he lost again. A year later, he ran for the California 
Assembly– and lost. Yet he tirelessly continued 
to support his district, befriending bartenders, construction 
unions, and local Chinese grocers. This earned him the affectionate title, 
the "mayor of Castro Street.” And when he ran his third campaign for 
the Board of Supervisors in 1977, Harvey finally won the seat– becoming one of the first openly gay 
public officials in US history. Elated, Milk arrived in office determined 
to make lasting change. He immediately introduced a bill outlawing
discrimination on the grounds of sexuality and launched a major clean-up of the city. But not everyone was happy 
with this direction. Anti-gay sentiment was gaining national 
momentum, especially in the form of 
California’s Proposition 6. The proposition, which sought 
to make it illegal for homosexuals to work 
in Californian schools, would prove to be the biggest battle 
of Milk’s career. Supporters of Prop 6 attacked 
the LGBT community, calling them unfit to work with students. But Milk urged them not to hide in fear: “Come out to your relatives. Come out to your friends, 
if indeed they are your friends. Come out to your neighbors, 
to your fellow workers… break down the myths. Destroy the lies and distortions. For your sake. For their sake.” Alongside other activists, he ran an incandescent campaign 
against hate. On November 7, 1978, Prop 6 was defeated in a landslide. It was proof that Milk’s message was 
gaining traction. But just twenty days after this 
inspiring victory, he was assassinated at City Hall– killed alongside San Francisco 
Mayor George Moscone. Both men had been murdered by Dan White, a former fellow supervisor, who had positioned himself against those 
he called "radicals, social deviates and incorrigibles.” He had frequently clashed with Harvey 
at Board meetings, and resented the spirit of change 
which Milk personified for many. The night of Milk's murder, thousands marched by candlelight 
through the city. In the wake of this tragedy, yet another injustice arose. In a highly controversial verdict, White received a sentence of only seven 
years and eight months– a decision that sparked uproar 
throughout the city in what became known as 
the White Night Riots. But even after his death, Milk continued to preach 
his hopeful cause. He left his friends and followers a total 
of three different tapes to be played in the event 
of his assassination. They leave us with a call to action, and a reminder that everyone is welcome
in the fight against injustice: "I ask for the movement to continue… and if a bullet should enter my brain, let that bullet destroy 
every closet door…”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Harvey Milk believed that gay youth should
Options: A. be treated in conversion therapy, B. ignore their sexual orientation until they turn 21, C. be helped by gay adults to fight the prejudice and discrimination against them, D. be prohibited from joining gay rights organizations
Correct Option: C

A decline in activism and mobilization, B. Increased representation and inclusivity in politics, C. A stronger emphasis on law enforcement, D. A reduction in government services Correct Option: B
Question 11: What can be said about the effectiveness of Harvey Milk's approach to addressing social injustices and promoting LGBT rights? Options: A. It was ineffective and led to no significant change, B. It was moderately successful, but had limited impact, C. It was highly effective in promoting social justice and LGBT rights, and continues to inspire contemporary movements, D. It was only effective in the short-term Correct Option: C
Question 12: What justification can be made for the importance of representation and inclusivity in politics, using Harvey Milk's legacy as an example? Options: A. Representation and inclusivity are not important in politics, B. Representation and inclusivity are only important for marginalized groups, C. Representation and inclusivity are crucial in politics, as they allow for diverse perspectives and promote social justice, D. Representation and inclusivity are only important for LGBT individuals Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

Although the wording is not identical, the intent and content of Question 4 align with the ground truth MCQ. Both questions relate to Harvey Milk's views on gay rights and his approach to addressing the issues faced by the LGBT community. The correct option in Question 4 (C. He believed gay rights could not be won from the closet) is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (C. be helped by gay adults to fight the prejudice and discrimination against them), as both convey Milk's emphasis on openness and community support in the fight for gay rights.

However, it's worth noting that there isn't a perfect match among the generated MCQs for the ground truth MCQ. The generated MCQs focus more on Harvey Milk's biography, philosophy, and legacy, whereas the ground truth MCQ specifically addresses his views on gay youth.
